Award.AbstractNarration:
AST-1219836

This award provides critical support to continue operating the Public Observatory at the National Air and Space Museum (NASM) beyond the initial two-year period of construction, opening, and initial operation, and to keep it viable until it can become a permanent fully endowed education and public outreach feature on the National Mall.

Visitors look through a fully professional telescope and an array of smaller specialized solar telescopes and have their experience enhanced and deepened by activity-based programming included in the observatory, adjacent to it, and in the Museum proper. NASM staff have successfully tested programs that synergistically combine the planetarium, the observatory, gallery tours and discovery stations, using support from several sources, including previous NSF awards. This has led to the Observatory becoming part of a major capital campaign to ensure its longevity. The present bridge award will support daytime and evening programming at the Observatory, increasing daily informal access by the public. It will also provide an effective training ground for undergraduate science, mathematics, engineering and technology (SMET) students to act as mentors and guides, learning to communicate the excitement of their science.

The heightened positive visibility of an SMET facility on the National Mall makes the clear intellectual statement that astronomy is part of our culture, and the Public Observatory is a physical personification of the Smithsonian's goal to improve science literacy in the Nation. The Observatory also makes visible the national observatory system, and symbolizes the merit-based philosophy of that system. In these first two years, trained astronomy educators, interns, paid student Explainers and a host of volunteers enabled over 100,000 looks through telescopes by tens of thousands of people, in all categories imaginable from casual tourists to professional astronomers to local families to foreign travelers, to school and day camp groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum’s Public Observatory is a place where members of the public get the chance to become astronomers. Visitors use powerful telescopes to observe the Sun, Moon, and planets, guided by knowledgeable staff and volunteers. And they walk away with new knowledge and understanding about the objects they observe and about how this understanding is obtained and advanced through observatories and scientific inquiry.

The Public Observatory’s educational programming accomplishes these outcomes through a variety of activities, all centered around providing access to the telescopes, both during the daytime and the nighttime, and training the staff and volunteers who lead visitors in activities at the Observatory.  This is a report on activities for the period Sept 1 2012 to August 31 2014 funded by NSF.  The seed funds provided by NSF led to an endowment from the Thomas W. Haas Foundation for continued activities and programming.

Visitors had the opportunity to participate in a variety of activities at the Observatory.  During the daytime, they could look at the Sun through a white-light projection device called a Sun Gun, as well as through hydrogen-alpha and calcium-K telescopes. Visitors also used the Cook 16-inch Boller & Chivens telescope to observe Venus and its phases during part of the year when it was in good view.  When the Moon was up, visitors observed it through an 85mm refractor or through binoculars. During the nighttime, visitors used the Cook 16-inch Boller & Chivens and portable telescopes to observe the planets Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune; a variety of double stars; Comet PanSTARRS; the Orion Nebula; the Pleiades star cluster; and the Moon.  Whenever the Observatory is open, a live view through one of the telescopes was streamed online for visitors who were unable to travel to the Smithsonian. In addition to observing, there were regularly scheduled “Astronomy Chats” at the Observatory during which visitors conversed directly with an astronomer who is actively engaged in research.

During the grant period, the Observatory was open for a total of 1,052 hours, and we interacted with visitors taking 110,618 “looks” through the telescopes. We estimate that about 55,000 individuals experienced the Observatory, since many visitors look through more than one telescope during their visit and thus learn about a wider variety of astronomical phenomena and observing techniques. There were also 72 Astronomy Chats, each an hour long, with 3830 visitors participating overall. .  

The majority of this activity took place during the daytime, the time when our target audience visits the National Mall. Visitors took over 110,000 “looks” through the telescopes during the 1017 hours of daytime programming during the grant period. Evening programs took place on average about once per month, and visitors took over 4,000 “looks” through the telescopes during 35 hours of evening programming.

When the weather didn’t permit observing during the hours when the Observatory was scheduled to be open, Observatory staff and volunteers facilitated educational activities in the astronomy-related galleries of NASM: Explore the Universe and Exploring the Planets. Around 55,000 visitors participated in these activities in over 7,000 hours of indoor programming throughout the grant period.  The activities include Touch a Falling Star, about meteorites; Cosmic Survey, about the size and scale of objects in the Universe; Looking through a Black Hole, about gravitational lensing and black holes; Decoding Starlight, about spectroscopy; and Maps and Models, about using tools like star charts, astrolabes, and quadrants.
